Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 51331-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
June 2018 
 
 
 
Enhancing Regional Knowledge Sharing 
Partnerships 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) aims to support the deepening of 
knowledge sharing between developing countries through the Regional Knowledge Sharing 
Initiative (RKSI), specifically in sharing development-related knowledge between developing 
member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and drawing on the experience 
of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) in promoting and supporting rapid economic growth over 
the past 30 years. 
 
2.  The TA will support the identification, development, and sharing of knowledge solutions in 
DMCs,  consistent  with  ADB’s  Midterm  Review  of  Strategy  2020  and  country  partnership 
strategies for participating DMCs.1 RKSI will implement this TA in collaboration with partner 
institutions in the PRC and other DMCs, with ADB as knowledge intermediary. The TA is not 
included in ADB’s country operations business plans for participating DMCs.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Asia  and  the  Pacific  has  achieved  significant  economic  success  in  recent  years, 
accounting for more than half of global economic growth. However, more than 300 million people 
in the region live in absolute poverty. To achieve the Sustainable Development Goals in 2030 and 
eliminate absolute poverty, consistent progress in sustainable and inclusive growth is required. 
Sharing quality and practical development knowledge plays a vital role in formulating effective 
policies toward attaining these goals. 
 
4.  The PRC has achieved an annual average growth rate of almost 10% in the past 30 years. 
This sustained economic growth helped lift more than 800 million of its citizens out of poverty and 
kept the PRC on track to eliminate absolute poverty by 2020, as defined by its national poverty 
threshold. Over the course of its development, the PRC experienced one of the most rapid 
urbanization paces in history. The share of urban residents in the PRC doubled from 25.3% in 
1987 to more than 50.0% of its population in 2012, an increase of more than 20 million urban 
residents every year.3 The PRC’s population, however, is aging at a faster rate than in other 
countries. 
 
5.  Within the PRC, adaption to rapid changes in economic conditions and transformation 
resulted in a variety of policy responses that were piloted at local levels. These decentralized 
experiments were then fed into the formulation of national policies. The PRC’s development 
experience thus constitutes a diverse set of policy experiments and lessons that can be shared 
with other DMCs. 
 
6.  The number of institutions in the region and in the PRC that work on various development 
issues has been growing in recent years, and some are becoming internationally competitive and 
well regarded. However, not all knowledge produced is readily accessible to DMC counterparts 
outside the PRC. 
 
                                                
1  ADB. 2014. Midterm Review of Strategy 2020: Meeting the Challenges of a Transforming Asia and Pacific. Manila. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 21 February 2018. 
3  The PRC’s current urbanization policy would further increase the percentage of urban residents to 60% of the total 
population by 2020.

2 
7.  ADB’s Strategy 2020 highlighted knowledge solutions as one of the five development 
drivers in Asia and the Pacific. Many ADB country partnership strategies for DMCs also include 
knowledge solutions. As these DMCs develop into middle-income economies and beyond, the 
PRC’s experience in navigating and transcending the challenges of middle-income traps would 
be constructive and relevant, especially as the PRC is expected to grow into the world’s largest 
economy within the next decade. 
 
8.  To promote cooperation between DMCs, the Government of the PRC and ADB launched 
RKSI on 30 August 2012 with the mandate to foster knowledge sharing. This was intended to 
increase collaboration between DMCs and promote regional cooperation and integration. RKSI 
provides  a  platform  for  knowledge  exchange  between  ADB’s  DMCs,  promotes  regional 
knowledge-sharing  events  that  build  on  knowledge  partnerships,  and  aims  to  improve 
coordination and serve as a catalyst for bilateral and multilateral knowledge sharing. 
 
9.  The implementation of the TA through RKSI enables the sharing of best practices and 
lessons from development programs and projects, including from ADB’s operations. This helps 
improve  the  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  government  and  international  assistance.  The 
multiplier effect increases through the online knowledge dissemination of best practices and policy 
lessons. RKSI will support themes under this TA that align with the current priorities of ADB’s 
strategic  focus,  such  as  (i)  poverty  reduction  and  inclusive  growth,  (ii)  urban  and  social 
development, (iii) environment and climate change, (iv) regional cooperation and integration, and 
(v) high technology and innovation. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: (i) regional cooperation and sustained 
knowledge sharing between the PRC and other DMCs has been enhanced; and (ii) the quality of 
development policies implemented in the PRC and other DMCs has improved. The TA will have 
the following outcome: the capacity of key institutions and knowledge networks in the PRC and 
other DMCs to address emerging development issues has been strengthened.4 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  Output 1: Awareness of the PRC and other DMCs on emerging development issues 
enhanced. The TA’s main vehicles for improving awareness of emerging development issues are 
knowledge-sharing events.  ADB will organize and support demand-based workshops, seminars, 
training, conferences, forums, study tours, and other events with partner institutions; and will help 
DMC participants increase their understanding of development issues and policy implications. 
ADB will share and discuss experiences, lessons, and best practices from the PRC and other 
countries. It will disseminate presentations, videos, and multimedia products related to the events 
through the RKSI website and other multimedia channels. ADB will also conduct surveys to 
capture client demand and post-event evaluations to ensure the effectiveness of knowledge 
sharing. The TA will primarily provide support for resource persons and international participants. 
 
12.  Output  2:  Knowledge  products  produced  and  disseminated.  Knowledge-sharing 
events will generate knowledge products, including workshop papers, case studies, conference 
proceedings  or  other  publications,  and  multilingual  video  clips.  The  TA  will  support  the 
                                                
4  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
development, production, translation, and dissemination of high-quality knowledge products to 
highlight selected knowledge solutions and to ensure broad access to participants from different 
DMCs. ADB will publish at least eight knowledge products under the TA. ADB and a knowledge 
partner will jointly determine the ultimate method of dissemination, whether in print or in electronic 
format. The TA will also foster a thematic approach to producing knowledge products with ADB 
partners. 
 
13.  Output 3: Knowledge networks strengthened and expanded. The TA will leverage 
ADB-supported subregional networks such as the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
and Greater Mekong Subregion programs. Building on past and ongoing cooperation between 
ADB and the PRC, the TA will further develop triangular cooperation and focus on knowledge 
sharing between DMCs, with ADB playing an intermediary role.5 To better share the PRC’s 
development experience, ADB will select eminent knowledge institutions and research think tanks 
in the PRC and within the region to initiate new partnerships and further expand the knowledge 
networks through memorandums of understanding or knowledge partnership agreements. 
 
14.  Output 4: RKSI website enhanced as a platform for knowledge sharing. The RKSI 
website is a depository of knowledge products from RKSI events and knowledge products related 
to collaboration between DMCs. Under the TA, ADB will enhance the RKSI website and increase 
its  interactive  elements  to  allow  for  broad-based  interaction  with  knowledge  partners  and 
stakeholders. ADB will upload and disseminate all events and knowledge products through the 
RKSI website on a timely basis. ADB will also improve the user-friendliness of the website by 
creating online knowledge modules, and further explore the use of multimedia and newsletters to 
enhance the online dissemination of knowledge. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $937,500, of which $750,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by the People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund6 and 
administered by ADB. Knowledge sharing events and services will leverage other ADB events 
and resources. Participating DMCs will provide in-kind contributions for various counterpart 
activities and support for joint knowledge-sharing activities. The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer the TA, with the Office of the Director General at the East Asia 
Department (EARD) as the focal point. EARD will assign ADB staff to manage RKSI. EARD, 
through RKSI, will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; organize workshops; and provide 
staff to act as resource persons in the workshops. In consultation with the PRC government, RKSI 
will work with other ADB departments and external knowledge partners to finalize the knowledge 
partnerships and activities under the TA. RKSI will implement the TA between 1 July 2018 and 
1 July 2020. EARD, through RKSI, will discuss TA implementation and monitoring with the PRC’s 
Ministry of Finance and update the People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional 
Cooperation Fund from time to time, as required. 
 
                                                
5  To date, RKSI has successfully supported the PRC and its partners in the funding and implementation of 12 flagship 
knowledge-sharing events, co-sponsorship of 27 knowledge events, and publication of 8 knowledge products and 
67 video clips, reaching more than 3,500 participants. 
6  The fund was originally named “People’s Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund” in 
the 2005 Board paper.

4 
17.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Indicative Implementation Arrangements

RKSI)

RKSI) in collaboration with various ADB departments (including 
resident missions), sector and thematic groups, external knowledge 
partners, and selected government agencies and organizations.

ADB = Asian Development Bank, ICS = individual consultant selection, RKSI = Regional Knowledge Sharing Initiative. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
18.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.7 ADB will engage individual international consultants for 10 person-months and 
individual national consultants for 70 person-months for the knowledge-sharing activities to be 
funded under the TA. ADB will engage the individual consultants rather than firms since there will 
be multiple partnerships with different institutions under the TA,  covering various forms of 
knowledge collaboration with differing consultancy needs; most of these activities and required 
inputs cannot yet be identified at the time of TA processing, prior to consultations with knowledge 
partners. The TA will also finance regional knowledge-sharing activities, including resource 
persons, participants, and the preparation and finalization of knowledge products. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development Bank administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 
to be financed on a grant basis by the People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional 
Cooperation Fund for Enhancing Regional Knowledge Sharing Partnerships, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board. 
                                                
7  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Awareness of the PRC and other DMCs on emerging development issues enhanced 
1.1 Hold discussions on knowledge-sharing events (either seminars or workshops) held with partner 
institutions to decide on partnerships and collaboration by December 2018 
1.2 Conduct at least 3 knowledge-sharing events conducted, present background papers, and publish 
presentations and videos on websites by June 2019 
1.3 Produce video clips by December 2019 
 
2.  Knowledge products produced and disseminated 
2.1 Draft at least 2 knowledge products by June 2019 
2.2 Publish final knowledge products by December 2019 
 
3.  Knowledge networks strengthened and expanded 
3.1 Initiate at least 1 new PRC knowledge partnership by December 2019 
 
4.  RKSI website enhanced as a platform for knowledge sharing 
4.1 Improve website use; mailing list, and potentially an e-forum, for further multimedia dissemination of 
knowledge products by December 2019

People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund: $750,000

Not applicable

participating DMCs will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, policy documents and guidelines, 
statistical data, information, office space, office supplies, and other in-kind contributions. The value of government 
contribution is estimated to account for 20% of the total TA cost.
